records.text: I've been thinking about the xz backdoor today. A brilliant part is that it was not visible in regular code inspection and injected itself when you built from the source codeThe overlooked part is that, in configure based packages, you are not really building from pure source.  You begin the build by executing a configure script, which is essentially an opaque binary that you simply trust. The concept of bundling code with a required tool to build and install it is flawed.

records.text: I've been thinking about the xz backdoor today. A brilliant part is that it was not visible in regular code inspection and injected itself when you built from the source codeThe overlooked part is that, in configure based packages, you are not really building from pure source.  You begin the build by executing a configure script, which is essentially an opaque binary that you simply trust. The concept of bundling code with a required tool to build and install it is flawed.

records.text: I've been thinking about the xz backdoor today. A brilliant part is that it was not visible in regular code inspection and injected itself when you built from the source codeThe overlooked part is that, in configure based packages, you are not really building from pure source.  You begin the build by executing a configure script, which is essentially an opaque binary that you simply trust. The concept of bundling code with a required tool to build and install it is flawed.
